Award.AwardTitle: Development of Large-Scale Electric Fields in the Inner Magnetosphere during Substorms
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will focus on temporal variations of electric fields in Earth's magnetosphere that are associated with the onset of a magnetic substorm. It will use data from the THEMIS and Cluster spacecraft as well as the THEMIS ground-based imaging array to precisely determine the time of substorm onset. Data from the THEMIS spacecraft will be used to determine the time difference between substorm auroral onset and the electromagnetic field and Poynting flux responses. These results can then be used to determine the propagation path of energy that lead to the formation of subauroral polarization streams (SAPS). SAPS are a major magnetosphere-ionosphere coupling phenomenon associated with region 2 FACs flowing into the subauroral ionosphere in the premidnight sector. For quantitative understanding of disturbances in the inner magnetosphere during substorms, it is essential to determine the transmission path of electromagnetic energy released in the magnetotail at substorm onset towards the inner magnetosphere, as well as the promptness and spatial distribution of this response. While a number of studies have been conducted for quasi-steady distributions of SAPS electric fields, this project will focus on temporal variations of electric fields associated with substorm onset.

The coupling of electromagnetic energy from the magnetosphere to the ionosphere is one of the most important processes that affect space weather. This project will investigate an important component of magnetosphere-ionosphere coupling that is associated with electric fields generated at the onset of a magnetic substorm.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Thus grant supported research of electromagnetic energy transport in Geospace, which plays an essential role in sudden commencements (abrupt jumps in the Earth’s magnetic field) and substorm auroral onset (breakup of aurora). This grant research aimed at quantifying energy transport processes by measuring evolution of electromagnetic field variations and Poynting flux as a direct measure of energy transport. To quantify the energy transport processes associated with substorms, we used the NSF-supported SuperDARN radars, THEMIS all-sky imagers, and ground magnetometers (McMac and THEMIS). Other datasets included the THEMIS, Cluster and CHAMP satellites.

As major outcomes, this research determined (1) energy transport from the polar cap to auroral oval as meso-scale flow channels for triggering substorm auroral onset, (2) current system associated with substorm auroral onset, (3) local time dependence of electric field responses to solar wind shocks. Particularly, the work of (1) led to reveal the day-night coupling process in the Earth’s ionosphere via localized fast flows as triggers of nightside auroral brightening. All these works have been published in peer-reviewed journals and presented in scientific conferences.

This project supported young researchers at UCLA, Yukitoshi Nishimura (PI) and Xiaoyan Xing (coI) under supervision by Professor Larry Lyons (coI). Through this research, Y. N. were trained to handle satellite, imager and radar data, and X. X. was trained to use satellite data. This funding was also used to support Ying Zou, who was a female graduate student of UCLA and recently finished her Ph.D. This project facilitated collaborations between UCLA and national and international institutes. Those include Vassilis Angelopoulos (UCLA), Stephen Mende (UCB), Naoko Takahashi (Tohoku University), Yohei Miyake (Kobe University) and H. Kwon (Kyung Hee University), Kazuo Shiokawa (Japan), Eric Donovan (Canada), and Herman Luhr (Germany).
